title: London, BL, Add. 12150
Titus, and Clemens, and the Caesarean [Eusebius]
There are completed in this volume three books,Titus, and Clemens, and the Caesarean.
Recognitions of Clement of Rome, the disciple of S. Peter
first discourse, comprising the first three books of the Latin version of Rufinus, and the first chapter of the fourth book, as far as the words apud Tripolim nobis hiemandiun denunciavimus.
third (discourse), against the heathens, corresponding to the tenth homily of the original Greek
fourth (discourse), corresponding to the eleventh homily of the Greek
From Tripolis in Phoenicia , corresponding to the twelfth homily of the Greek, from the beginning to the end of § 25, and the thirteenth homily
fourteenth discourse, corresponding to the fourteenth homily of the Greek
Discourses of Titus, bishop of Bosra, or Bostra, against the Manichaeans
Here ends the four discourses of Titus of Bostra against the Manichaeans, translated from Greek into Aramaic.
first discourse
second discourse
third discourse
fourth discourse
Treatise of Eusebius of Caesarea on the Theophania (περὶ θεοφανεἰας) or Divine Manifestation of our Lord, in five books
first book
second book with the special title against the Philosophers
third book
fourth book
fifth book
History of the Confessors, or Martyrs, in Palestine by Eusebius of Caesarea
Panegyric on the Christian Martyrs by Eusebius
Martyrology, the greater part of which, relating to the western martyrs, is arranged according to the order of the Syrian months, from the first Kānūn to the second Teshrī
Ecclesiastical History
syrTitle: ܐܫ]ܬܠܡܘ ܒܦܢܩܝܬܐ ܗܕܐ ܟ̈ܬܒܐ ܬ̈ܠܬܐ ܛܛܘܣ ܘܩܠܡܣ ܘܩܣܪܝܐ

placeName: Imperial Public Library at St. Petersburg
finalRubrics: [ܐܫ]ܬܠܡܘ ܒܦܢܩܝܬܐ ܗܕܐ ܟ̈ܬܒܐ ܬ̈ܠܬܐ ܛܛܘܣ ܘܩܠܡܣ ܘܩܣܪܝܐ
There are completed in this volume three books, Titus , and Clemens , and the Caesarean .
ܫܠܡ ܠܡܟܬܒ ܡܡܠܠܐ ܩܕܡܝܐ ܕܩܠܡܣ
ܫܠܡ ܡ̈ܐܡܪܐ ܐܪ̈ܒܥܐ ܕܛܛܘܣ ܕܠܘܩܒܠ ܡܢܝ̈ܢܝܐ ܕܡܦܩܝܢ ܡܢ ܝܘܿܢܝܐ ܠܐܪܡܝܐ
Here ends the four discourses of Titus of Bostra against the Manichaeans, translated from Greek into Aramaic.
ܫܠܡ ܠܡܟܬܒ ܚܡ̈ܫܐ ܣܦܪ̈ܝܢ ܕܐܘܣܒܣ ܩܣܪܝܐ ܕܡܬܩܪܝܢ ܕܕܢܚܐ ܐܠܗܝܐ.
ܫܠܡܘ ܫ̈ܪܒܐ ܕܬܫ̈ܥܝܬܐ ܕܢܨܚ̈ܢܝܗܘܢ ܕܡܘ̈ܕܝܢܐ ܩ̈ܕܝܫܐ ܕܒܦܠܣܛܝܢܐ.
colophons: Colophon Doxology On fol. 254a, 3rd col., we read the colophon, written with green paint (see also fol. 227b ): [ܐܫ]ܬܠܡܘ ܒܦܢܩܝܬܐ ܗܕܐ ܟ̈ܬܒܐ ܬ̈ܠܬܐ ܛܛܘܣ ܘܩܠܡܣ ܘܩܣܪܝܐ There are completed in this volume three books, Titus , and Clemens , and the Caesarean . This is followed by the doxology (written with yellow paint, see also fol. 229b ), and by the note: ܐܫܬܠܡܬ ܦܢܩܝܕܬܐ$ ܗܕܐ ܒܝܪܚ ܬܫܪܝ ܫܢܬ ܫܒ[ܥܡـ]ܐܐ [ܘܥ]ܣܪܝܢ ܘܬܠܬ ܒ[ܐ]ܘܪܗܝ [ܡܕܝܢܬܐ ܕ]ܒܝܬ [ܢܗ]ܪܝܢ . . . ܦܢܩܝܬܐ is the oldest form of the word, from πινακίδὶον . It usually becomes, by assimiliation, ܦܢܩܝܬܐ; and is sometimes corrupted into ܦܢܩܝܢܬܐ, according to the analogy of ܡܕܝܢܬܐ ,ܣܦܝܢܬܐ, etc. This volume was finished in the month of the latter Teshrī, in the year 723 ( A.D. 412 ), at Urhāi (Edessa) , a city of Beth-Nahrīn (Mesopotamia) ……….
otherLimit: ܬܫܥܝܬܐ ܕܩܠܝܡܝܣ ܐܝܢܐ ܕܢܩܝܦ ܗܘܐ ܠܫܡܥܘܢ ܟܐܦܐ
[ܐܫ]ܬܠܡܘ ܒܦܢܩܝܬܐ ܗܕܐ ܟ̈ܬܒܐ ܬ̈ܠܬܐ ܛܛܘܣ ܘܩܠܡܣ ܘܩܣܪܝܐ
ܐܫܬܠܡܬ ܦܢܩܝܕܬܐ$ ܗܕܐ ܒܝܪܚ ܬܫܪܝ ܫܢܬ ܫܒ[ܥܡـ]ܐܐ [ܘܥ]ܣܪܝܢ ܘܬܠܬ ܒ[ܐ]ܘܪܗܝ [ܡܕܝܢܬܐ ܕ]ܒܝܬ [ܢܗ]ܪܝܢ . . .

ܚܙܘ ܐܚ̈ܝ ܐܢܗ̣ܘ ܕܡܬܦܣܩܐ ܚܪܬܗ ܕܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܥܬܝܩܐ ܘܐܒܕܐ ܥܡ ܗ̇ܘ ܡܕܡ ܕܚܬ݂ܡ ܘܐܫܠܡ ܒܗ ܟܬܘܒܗ. ܗܟܢܐ ܟܬܝܒ ܗܘܐ ܒܗ̇ ܒܚܪܬܗ ܕܐܬܟܬ݂ܒ ܠܡ ܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܒܐܘܪܗܝ ܡܕܝܢܬܐ ܕܒܝܬ ܢܗܪܝܢ ܒܐܝܕ̈ܝ ܐܢܫ ܕܡܬܩܪܐ ܝܥܩܘܒ ܒܫܢܬ ܫܒܥܡܐܐ ܘܥܣܪܝܢ ܘܬܠܬ ܒܐܝܪܚ ܬܫܪܝܢ ܐܚܪܝ ܐܫܬܠܡ. ܘܐܝܟ ܡܕܡ ܕܟܬܝܒ ܗܘܐ ܬܡܢ ܟܬܒ݁ܬ ܐܦ ܗܪܟܐ ܕܠܐ ܬܘܣܦܬܐ܀ ܘܗܠܝܢ ܕܗܪܟܐ ܟܬܒ݁ܬ ܐܢܝ̈ܢ ܒܫܢܬ ܐܠܦ ܘ܏ܫܨܚ ܒܕܝܘ̈ܢܝܐ..
